reviewText:
Note: video review embedded below.

Revolver360 is, at a glance, complete and absolute absurdity. Picture a bullet hell shooter drenched in futuristic neon blue which fully rotates at the press of a button, existing in three dimensions as you fly sideways through waves of enemies while trying to keep up with the madness on screen.

The number of systems and mechanics at work at any given time in Revolver is in itself intimidating, which when paired with its genre-typical difficulty level and the added intensity of a third dimension, can feel like borderline excess for the sake of it. But Revolver pulls it all off because underneath the inscrutable exterior there’s a very deep, developed formula at work, all focused around an elaborate shooting and scoring system that is only as invasive as you want it to be.

Different types of shots affect different enemies, various meters are raised by particular stimuli, and multiple paths through levels create even more room for experimentation. Revolver fully commits itself to being as complex and unique as possible within the capabilities of its systems, and while this means it’s likely the least accessible shoot’em’up I’ve played in a very long time, its desire to nurture and expand the boundaries of advanced play feels like a justified trade off.

Revolver expresses this best in its challenge mode, which features 50 quick, extremely focused missions which give you a specific task to complete in a short period of time. To me these felt less like fun bonuses to the main game, but rather a comprehensive tutorial detailing the minutia of Revolver’s intricate mechanics and how best to use them. This is accomplished through the challenges themselves, and also the contextual hint system which drip feeds you information in a way that is much easier to parse given you can immediately apply it to an appropriate situation.

Returning to Revolver’s main stages after completing a number of these, I was surprised just how much more I understood about the game I had already beaten once, and how significantly more capable that had made me where simply reading a manual and playing the game had not. I also began to appreciate all the little things I hadn’t even noticed before, like the finer points of the scoring system or how to best utilize the rotation feature to line up enemies, which further solidified in me the idea that Revolver had fully thought through each of its mechanics and the interplay that develops between them. The more I was able to understand the more I enjoyed playing, and it made me wish that other games would be as thorough in their initiations.

But even if you aren’t interested in getting deep into Revolver’s metagame it’s still a fascinating beast of a bullet hell shooter to play around with. Rotating your ship is an ingenious hook that somehow never manages to feel clumsy or obscure important information (an even more impressive task when put up against Revolver’s brainmelting cyberpunk visual style).

It’s a “cool” that didn’t need explaining; a “cool” which leaked out of the screen like a kettle getting ready to blow its top and told me that I better get ready. And then the game started and all pretenses of restraint evaporated as Revolver boldly declared that it wasn’t going to settle for being just enough shoot’em’up and neither should you.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dW_Tr5E-yts
You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

reviewText: Fast, blue, stylish and clean. Ikaruga's wilder, more futuristic cousin I think. That's a good place to start when discussing RE:ACTOR. From Cross Eaglet, this bullet hell shmup takes a simple premise and adds a unique mechanic, instead of polarity, you're dealing with rotation. The field of play can be rotated along a 360 degree axis around your ship. In effect, you're flying through a cylinder" as opposed to a flat playfield as is often the case
date: with enemies swirling all around you
recommended: and the landscape forming a three dimensional tube that often branches and splits
hoursPlayed: with numerous junctions appearing that will allow you to choose your route (this offers -immense- replayability as you high score hunt or figure out new routes through various stages).\n\nAs you rotate the field of view
voteText: the bullets also rotate
helpfulPercent: so a near impossible field to navigate suddenly becomes a flat line that's easy to dodge
votesHelpful: and all of a sudden the game forces you to think in three dimensions
votesTotal: with objects often coming at you from "depth" as well as from the top
commentsCount: front and back. It would be a bit easy to lose track were it not for the utterly gorgeous aesthetic which keeps things simple and easy to keep track of. Everything is presented in a washed out
column17: clean lines and clear presentation keep the game running at a flawless 60fps no matter what you're doing
column18: with everything maxed out on my rig the game looks nothing short of artistic (Oh god please let there be an occulus rift option down the line).\n\nAs is the norm for such japanese bullet hell games

column36: once you make it past the opening stage

column39: as any good bullet hell should be

reviewText:
I have an odd relationship with shmups because I'm not that great at them. I don't always manage to complete all of the highest regarded ones. The best just feel awesome to play, though.

This game has a silly name but the triggers (if on a controller) rotate the screen around the action. This lets you turn a screen full of bullets into a single line and then use a laser to blast the bullets apart for points. It sounds like a gimmick but it's a lot of fun and provides a really interesting challenge and a one of the most fun and unique scoring systems I've seen.

The rotation mechanic is also important because you auto-kill items and enemies that are in the background, which you can only see/target if you are rotated a certain way. There are sections where you have to keep your screen facing forward" to destroy obstacles in the way
date: while balancing the need to rotate to survive enemy shots.\n\nI think there may be 4 levels with bosses. I'm not sure because I have only managed to beat the stage 3 boss in the single mission mode. I'm definitely going back though
voteText: true

reviewText:
Overview: Shoot em Up


The Good

+ A cool mechanic that allows you to rotate the environment around you allowing you to avoid bullets, obstacles and enemies

+ Throughout the level you are given a choice in how you want to proceed providing good incentive for replays.

+ Great difficulty balance. The game appears hard at first but once you get use to the games mechanics the game becomes easier

+ 50 Challenges that will test your limits and patience.

+ Easy to see what's going on for the majority of the game


The Average

Lots of blue....

Fairly short game, if you are not a fan of the genre you could easily beat the game in 1-2 hours and never play it again.


Conclusion

Shoot em ups are not my favorite genre. I find them repetitive, however this game is really fun because it doesn't over use the amount of bullets on screen and the rotating mechanic is interesting enough to keep you engaged for a while.

reviewText: People who are looking for a Bullet Hell SHMUP with a new gimmick should really try this game]. It's got a great presentation, with great visuals, a decent soundtrack, and a unique revolving mechanic that allows you to place bullets for maximum points or to help you get out of an impossible situation. The live update for where you place on the leader boards really adds to making the player want to better their skills at destroying the most bullets as possible to increase the score multiplier. I really can't believe the game hasn't gotten any buzz.

reviewText:
An unique and quite challenging shmup with a twist. Literally. Being able to rotate the entire screen as you play, and honestly if you don't do that, you might as well consider yourself dead from the beginning. I consider myself lucky for completing it on my 3rd try, especially considering how panic inducing the last boss's patterns were.

Speaking of which, all the bullets and just the entire game is so glowy, that it's really difficult to read some patterns especially on the last boss, but I'll forgive it since the game as a whole was amazing. Also it ran at a perfect constant 60fps at 3840x2160 resolution on a laptop, so i feel it's quite well optimized.

Hoping we'll see more games from this creative dev...

reviewText:
I don't often write reviews, but for this game I thought I'd make an exception.  I happened to see it on the store front and checked out the video - at that point I knew the game was for me!

The game's unique gameplay mechanic is to rotate the world around your ship and this is exploited brilliantly to chain enemies and avoid walls of bullets.  I wouldn't describe the game as bullet hell, but more like a Cave shooter; there are plenty of bullets for sure, but every single one of them is there to be used to increase your multiplier.  Although you only get a single life, the game isn't so punishingly hard that you can't progress a few levels with some practice, but like any good shooter you can choose the risky play styles which could net you much more points at the expense of progress.

Graphically the game has a unique look to it, very reminiscent of the demoscene product cdak" by Quite and Orange.  On level three things get shaken up a bit which is welcomed at that point.  Musically this game is incredible
date: covering a wide range of styles but remaining high quality throughout
recommended:
and the soundtrack is right there in the game folder.

A fantastic game then and one that I'm sure I'll keep replaying not just for the score but for the sheer enjoyment of it.

9/10"

reviewText:
Yes. Yes! YES!

I haven't played a shoot 'em up this exhilarating in a long time. Fantastic visuals, killer soundtrack and most important of all, frenetic and satisfying-as-all-hell gameplay. If you like the genre at all, be it as a fun-seeking novice or as a hardcore veteran, buy the ♥♥♥♥ out of this, you owe it to yourself!

Admittedly it's a lot more hectic and overwhelming at times than most shoot 'em ups, and due to the unique revolving mechanic and sheer speed of gameplay. it's very hard (not impossible though) to evade taking damage due to the unique revolving mechanic it uses, but the game is designed for you to absorb a few hits, and this shouldn't take away from your enjoyment much if at all. I think the game mostly benefits because of the mechanic's ingenuity anyways, and I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Now if you'll excuse me, I'm gonna jump in for another round ;)

reviewText:
This game is something else!

At first glance it looks like a regular shump.

Then you discover that you can turn your camera around the X axis to avoid seemingly unavoidable projectile barrages, instantly, the game is more fun than you expected.

Then you learn that you can actually shoot down the projectiles with your special attacks, all of them, if you align your camera just right. Waiting for the screen to fill with bullets before you kill the enemy is a bad idea, right? Wrong, not in this game, turn your camera and clear them all in one shot! What is this!? I don't even...

Then you learn that you can do the same thing with multiple enemies, killing  them all in one shot.

Then you learn that you can combine all that and get even higher scores.

THEN YOUR HEAD WILL SPIN!

reviewText: This isn't your standard bullet-hell shooter. This is a shooter where you literally rotate the entire level in order to dodge bullets, avoid enemies and line up enemies and enemy bullets to rack up points. You have a laser used for extra damage and destroying bullets and a lock-on weapon used for destroying certain targets, as well as an overdrive attack that destroys all bullets in the area (handy for boss fights). Add in the impressive visuals, killer soundtrack and challenging gameplay and you have a game that every shmup fan should try out.

reviewText: I love it, and I'm really picky about the shootemups I like to play. The gameplay is fun without falling into bullet-hell masturbation, and being able to revolve the screen adds a really exciting mechanic to this style of game and it designs for it pretty well. On top of it, it's a very solid & responsive feeling shootemup.\nThe downsides are that the graphical style makes it hard to understand what's going on at certain times (nothing too frustrating, but certainly dont' expect to pick everything up on the first play), and there could stand to be a better introduction to the revolving mechanic opposed to throwing you straight into the fire. But then again, it does make re-playing pretty fun since there's hardly a dull moment.

reviewText: Revolver 360 is an STG (or Shmup") that is innovative in its mechanics whilst remaining respectful to the classics and fundamentals of the genre. To summarise
date: Revolver 360 is a 2.5D STG taking place in 4 stages
recommended: with branching paths and bosses at the end of each level. The player shoots enemies and objects coming from all directions in a 3D plane whilst moving within a rotatable cylindrical playing field. Bullets can be rotated-around and cancelled through abilities which use up constantly-recharging resources. The scoring system is based around cancelling bullets and enemy chaining (although the chaining is not nearly as strict as games like Dodonpachi
hoursPlayed: which is notorious for its perfection-demanding enemy chaining). There are also 50 short challenge levels which test the player's knowledge of the different game mechanics
voteText: as well as their memorisation.\n\nAs someone who usually plays STGs for survival and tends not to care about getting high scores
helpfulPercent: the scoring system in Revolver 360 is so addictive that it has gotten me hooked and trying to improve my scores regularly in spite of my preferences for survival play.\n\nThe scoring system is based around two multipliers: a first multiplier which is based on chaining enemy destruction
votesTotal: although this limit can temporarily be broken through using overdrive mode; the second multiplier is a count of how many bullets you have cancelled. Bullets are cancelled through destroying enemies as they are firing lasers
commentsCount: or using the emp shot (a powerful charge shot which breaks through blue beams which lasers cannot cancel) and overdrive
column16: which cancels all bullets on screen once activated. Larger enemies fire more bullets at lower health
column17: so the player has to be careful to leave them on as little health as possible to cancel as many bullets as possible. The effect this has on the gameplay is that it encourages players to be constantly taking risks
column18: as it requires them to rotate clouds of bullets directly towards them to cancel them out with a well-timed/positioned laser cancel. The nature of the first multiplier encourages players to mix up their main shot (which works as you would expect from a basic STG shot type) and their laser for the most optimal chaining. This combined with the fact that there are many routes to take throughout the meticulously-crafted and gorgeous levels (there are even secret routes!) means that there is a ton of player freedom and replay value."
column22: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
This game is gorgeous. It is gorgeous in its gameplay and most definitely in its graphics.

I have a mediocre laptop, so I'm surprised I could run such a detailed and vibrant game.

You're a small futuristic ship I guess, and you have the standard attacks you'd find in any side-scrolling bullet hell (well, not THAT many bullets, but still) shooter, like a normal dual laser shot, a bigger laser, an EMP, and a freakin' Overdrive that I still don't understand what it does b/c I didn't bother to read the manual (it's in the main menu after you finish configuring, choosing a name, and achieving the first achievement just for buying the game, sweet!).

basically they let you change bullets into points and increase your multiplier so you can have like billions of points OH BOY

The rotation mechanism is very interesting. What you see on your screen is not always the whole picture. There's enemies in the background, as well as ZOMG HUGE ASTEROIDS AND SPACE JUNK (and other crates that can help your ship but those aren't too frequent). So, how do you destroy these things if you can't see them at present? You rotate thorugh your 360 degree field of view, of course! That way, even though you're looking at your ship and the approaching enemies from the side, you can also blast background objects and enemies away, whether they're above or below you! It's a fascinating concept that really sets this game apart and makes it that much more enjoyable.

You really should get this game if you enjoy a challenge. It is a challenge, honestly. Not that you'll die all the time, of course. But y'know, you could just have rotated through the 3D space to avoid that humongous helicopter's laser.

Okay, whatever, just get the game already, it's breathtaking! No joke!

reviewText:
Short version: game's cheap and it's on par with Ikaruga in terms of both porting and game design. Get it.

Long version: I'm so happy there are more and more Japanese games appearing on Steam. Sure, some of them are ♥♥♥♥♥♥ dating sims but there are lots of gems still not released on the platform. Playism has been delivering (and translating, I believe) Japanese indie games for a while now through their site. Some of them make their way to Steam and they're always very well ported: there are always proper resolution config, control options and such. Revolver360 looks great, supports up to 4K resolutions (16:10 option is hidden under F10 key but that's a minor thing) and of course runs at 60FPS.

Revolver360 has been praised in shmup circles and rightfully so. It's a great take on the genre with 2D plane you can rotate to avoid bullets or find secrets in the background - see the trailer, it explains the basics pretty well. The game's as hardcore as you can get which is the main draw for me. This wouldn't matter if the mechanics weren't fun, of course, but they surely are. I only wish the game would use more colors as it's blue on blue for the most part but that's a design decision and who am I to teach the devs. The tutorial is hidden somewhat in the challenge mode, be sure to try that before trying to clear the main mode.

reviewText:
>> This review might be updated later with some extra info <<

DAAAAAAAMN! THIS GAME IS AWESOME!
REVOLVER360 RE:ACTOR is a shoot'em up game; but it has a very interesting difference from other games in this genre: you can rotate the enviroment!
For example, you can use this ability to line up several rows of enemies and destroy them at once or to avoid screen filling attacks. This ability also made the game a lot challenging since the enemies and some goodies are placed around the enviroment. In addition to this ability, you have access to a straight laser attack which can eliminate enemies and some projectiles, and an overdrive move which removes every projectile from the screen.
There are three modes to play in this game. I recommend completing the challenges before playing through Reactor mode to learn the basics.

Positive Points:
- The enviroment rotation mechanic is very innovative and has made the game unique
- Multiple paths in stages
- Nice difficulty (The game is hard at first. But when you get used to the mechanics it becomes easier.)
- Nice visuals and soundtracks (Soundtracks are bundled with the game.)

Negative Points:
- TOO MUCH BLUE COLOUR!

Notes:
- The game can freeze on launch due to one reason: downloading scoreboards. To avoid this, check ((Offline Mode)) in game's config file which is in the game's main directory.
- I haven't finished the game, so it's early to tell the game is short or not. I'll update the review later about this.

reviewText:
The only complaint I have about this game is that sometimes it is a bit difficult on the eyes for me-- but that's just me. You might have a different experience dependent on your color contrast and ideal monitor setup.

That said.

I am by no means an expert, professional shmup player. I love them, I have a passion for them, but I'm not spectacular at them. This game makes me feel like I'm a professional anyway. You will slowly learn the game as you continue practicing it, figuring out ways to make seemingly impossible attacks become trivial. You will watch yourself destroy massive hulking behemoths of nightmarish blue metal and you will feel invincible.

I often watch replays of top players just to watch the backgrounds, just to see the details in the landscapes that I'm otherwise not paying attention to. The optimization is top-notch, and I'll be shocked if the game runs at anything shy of 60FPS the entire time.

This game is absolutely worth full purchase value.

reviewText:
The only complaint I have about this game is that sometimes it is a bit difficult on the eyes for me-- but that's just me. You might have a different experience dependent on your color contrast and ideal monitor setup.

That said.

I am by no means an expert, professional shmup player. I love them, I have a passion for them, but I'm not spectacular at them. This game makes me feel like I'm a professional anyway. You will slowly learn the game as you continue practicing it, figuring out ways to make seemingly impossible attacks become trivial. You will watch yourself destroy massive hulking behemoths of nightmarish blue metal and you will feel invincible.

I often watch replays of top players just to watch the backgrounds, just to see the details in the landscapes that I'm otherwise not paying attention to. The optimization is top-notch, and I'll be shocked if the game runs at anything shy of 60FPS the entire time.

This game is absolutely worth full purchase value.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I love shoot 'em ups, but I will be the first to admit I am not very good at them.   One of the great things about this game is that it is very approachable for all skill levels.  In fact, I actually cleared this game (there are no continues, so every clear is a 1cc), which is a first for me as I have never cleared a shmup without using a continue (terrible thing to have to admit, I know).  It only took a few practice runs of the 2nd and 3rd stages, and a couple replays that I watched from the leaderboards to achieve this too.  However, there is alot more difficulty and depth in the scoring, plus numerous challenges to satisfy you after you have gotten that first clear.  In addition, each stage has multiple routes, some of which require conditions to unlock, so the stages have alot of replayability.  My favorite way to play this game is just practice one stage, experimenting with different routes and rotating in different areas to shift bullets for better scoring, or to find more items or destructible objects.

From the video and screenshots you can see that the graphics are very unique and original, and quite good too.  The first time you play this game, make sure you try the challenges first.  The beginning ones are what actually teach you to play the game.

The rotating mechanic is also very original.  It feels like you are actually changing the shape and pattern of the enemy bullets and I think this game is worth playing just for experiencing this neat new system alone.

reviewText:
At first glance, it looks and plays like regular bullet hell with possibility to chew bullets/convert them to bonus, but once you understand and master the revolving arena concept, you start to wonder - why no other game gives you this?
This changes the entire gameplay and adds interesting novelty to old and tired genre.
Other pros include great music and nice, tron-like graphics that actually work well even on semi-latest Intel IGPs.
The only cons are that the game is short (though it'll take you a while to complete it, I needed around 5h) and seems to be locked at 60fps (authors wrote in forums that they're considering changing it).

reviewText:
The perfect shoot-m-up that re-invents the classic SHUMP genre!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2cZsVXY-oWM

In this long awaited shooter from action masters Cross Eaglet, enemies are not just right in front of you. They're all around you! Using a unique perspective rotation mechanic, players can bring enemies and items into view, putting the odds in their favor in an otherwise impossible situation.

In Revolver 360 RE:ACTOR, you don't only have your bullets to save you. You're also armed with a powerful laser that pierces through weaker enemies, and a screen-clearing EMP. It's the exact kind of weaponry you're going to need if you hope to survive this harsh and hostile environment.

Use your weapons in concert with each other to toy with your enemies and reap higher score rewards. Killing your foes quickly is not always the best course of action. - Highly Recommended!

reviewText:
https://youtu.be/_ZjE5_vAwrc

A new twist on the shoot-em-up formula?  GET IT?  This game's gimmick is that you can rotate the level to avoid projectiles, find alternate routes and off screen enemies.  A mechanic that hasn't deeply explored in the genre and was fun to try.

This implementation falls a little short, the rotation can be a bit too dizzying and when combined with the ship direction not matching the scroll direction leads to a hard to digest visuals for the eyes.

The player weapons, enemy patterns and bosses however fell short and ended up being the standard faire seen in this style of game many times before.  Overall the rotation gimmick isn't enough to carry this game to the finish line but it's something more games should consider.

reviewText:
Poorly paced gameplay, if you enjoy dying for no reason without familiarising yourself to the game, or easing you into the game, this games for you

Me, I prefer well designed gameplay, which doesnt punish you for playing the game, & actually allows you to get used to the game

The gameplay is poor, as the game never eases you into the game

Plus it never tells you how to block or dodge the huge boulders & other objects it drops on you, over & over again, plus there's no tutorial

The challenges are laughably designed, the developer uses cheap shots forcing you to memorise what half ♥♥♥♥♥ pattern the developer wants you to perform in under 2 seconds

If you enjoy poorly designed gameplay & have telepathic mind reading skills, you'll love this game ...

I love bullet hell games, I've got tons on my samsung p900 android tablet, this game needs to tweak the gameplay seriously to allow the player to get into the game & figure out how to play the game

The amature designed gameplay & the poor pacing ruins the game

If you enjoy seeing the word failure every 5 seconds playing the challenge's, or the poorly designed pacing of the game in the main game, I wouldnt recommend this game

The developer obviously hasnt spent enough time testing the gameplay, or pacing the game properly, ruining the experience

Slow down the first few initial levels & ease the player into the game, allowing him to get accustomed to the game & the controls

Also some sort of tutorial on how to dodge the huge objects & crap it throws at you, or a message on how to dodge the massive incoming rocks & objects

reviewText:
Revolver360 has an awesome presentation — unfortunately the rest of the game is not quite up to par. The ability to turn the camera around 360 degrees seemed at bit gimmicky at first, once I got used to it I started to like it though.

The main problem of this game is the difficulty level: it’s just way too easy. I managed to beat it after just two hours. You can get hit countless times and still make it through the levels. This means you don’t really need to use the camera system that much, since even if you do get hit by offscreen enemies, it doesn’t really matter.

Still, there aren’t many recent 2D shooters with such a nice presentation and the game is definitely fun to play, so I can easily recommend this to any fans of the genre.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Very nice, albeit short, game, which puts a twist on 2d sidescrollan games. It's like Gradius, except you can tilt the angle of your vertical view, so an attack that would take up the whole screen can now be easily dodged by flipping it onto its side. It's a unique and polished ride. Be warned though, the game is not for the lighthearted. You get a good amount of health in the beginning to fend off damage, and you can repair your ship with pickups found through the game, but you only get one life, and if you die, it's game over. Bottom line, I have yet to beat the game, but I'm very close, and I still recommend this pretty little gem in my steam library.

reviewText:
First Impression:  As a casual SHUMPer and sucker for Japanese Indie games, this game is near the top of my import list.

+Good Music
+Great graphics that don't confuse me when playing
+It's fully translated in English (Rare for Japanese Indies)
+Great controller binding with explanations and demonstrations of mechanics on the same page.
+Spot-on handling
+Full manual for explaining all the entertwined mechanics.

-Limited (but growing) list of resolutions (Common with Japanese Imports)

R360R:A has really beaten me up and I am terrible at it, but it can't be blamed on the game.  I just can't wrap my head around the mechanics yet.  Because of that it is a challenge rather than a discouragement.  Very fun.

reviewText:
If you're a fan of shumps, this one here is not to be missed. 5 minutes into the game and I'm glad I made this purchase.

I don't mind the same old shumps so I wasn't expecting something innovative but... THIS GAME SHOOK ME UP. Rotating 360 degrees to avoid obstacles? That doesn't sound like it is anything wonderful, well, not until you've played it to experience it yourself.  I used a gamepad so rotating left/right is very natural, easy to manoeuvre.

There are 3 types of bullets - providing you the extra strategy and varies your play style so it is not just about blasting all you have and avoiding all you can (well you still have to do that to survive.. heh). However there's no guided tutorial in play about what the bullets do. All that's provided is a manual at the main menu for reading. You could just jump right into the game and try them out but I'd suggest to read about it firsthand.

reviewText:
Got this game for $5 in a Humble Bundle, and having a good deal of fun with it. Anyone who has enjoyed a 2D side-scrolling shooter should appreciate this game, because REVOLVER 360 RE:ACTOR is basically a long overdue update to this old genre of games. It literally adds an extra dimension, which impacts the game mechanics more than what one might expect! The interface is pretty futuristic, and the included soundtrack is a nice bonus.

Haven't played too much yet, but I can recommend it based on the fun it's already provided to me! Fun for casual gamers too (like me), but also diehards in the way Tetris can be competitive. GL HF!

Note: No multiplayer (other than scoreboard).

Edit: Just found out that the game is shorter than I thought, so I got through more of the game (%-wise) in my original few attempts that expected. A little bit of a disappointment, but I don't regret picking up this game.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
If you like more puzzley STGs like Ikaruga then this is right in your alley. I've gotten to rank 32 in the leaderboards so I feel like I've gotten a good understanding of the mechanics.

You have 3 types of shot. Normal, Laser, and I guess you could call it destroy. Normal rips up enemies but gives little score, laser shoots through enemies and builds score by giving a chain kill bonus, and destroy shoots through enemy blue/purp attacks and also leaves anything it hits near death. Normal shot is the only one that can hit enemies in the background which shares a different chain bonus from laser. You have limited laser shot that regens. Destroy uses meter that is shared with the overdrive power which when activated rapidly regens your laser as well as buffing your shot damage.

You can also rotate the map left and right to line up enemies for destroy/laser combos or to avoid shots that would normally hit. It is also crucial to rotate to be able to attack background objects that will give score.

There are background chests that hold powerups. You don't build up your shot like most STGs from powerups in this one. Instead they hold health, laser reload, or overdrive reload. They spawn the same powerup in the same location everytime so for score its important to know when you should be using your laser/destroy/overload abilities so that you don't waste any powerups.

It's quite a bit of fun once you get into the mechanics. There is also a challenge mode which helps you understand how to build score and utilitze the mechanics the best. Only minor problem I have is that this game is fairly short and the final boss at least in my opinion was somewhat lackluster. But this is an indie STG which has really amazing mechanics so I can't get too hard on it.

The brightness (and afaik the lack of ability to turn it down) is another minor problem but you get used to it.

tl;dr if you like ikaruga and can deal with the fact that this is an indie game and thus doesn't have as much production values or as tuned boss fights as some other STGs then you'll be in for a treat.
